data.title: 'Simply Streisand,' Drawing Marathon: What's happening this week around Binghamton
data.meta_description: Don't have plans for the week? We've got you covered.
data.text:
An impersonator of a legendary diva will stop by Binghamton's Forum Theatre on Saturday.

Learn more in our roundup of 10 things to do in Binghamton and throughout the Southern Tier:

1. Tri-Cities Opera presents 'Simply Streisand'

Tri-Cities Opera in Binghamton is hosting Barbra Streisand impersonator Carla Del Villaggio, who will bring her "Simply Streisand" show to the Broome County Forum Theatre at 7:30 p.m. Saturday. Del Villaggio is an alumna of Binghamton University’s graduate opera program and the TCO Resident Artist Training Program. She now tours internationally as a Streisand tribute artist. The concert will include performances by TCO's resident artists. The lobby will open at 6:30 p.m. for a silent auction, with seating at 7. Tickets are $59 for premium orchestra seating, $39 for regular orchestra seating and $19 for value orchestra seating. The Forum Theatre is at 236 Washington St. For more information, call 607-772-0400 or go to tricitiesopera.com/simplystreisand.

2. Magician and balloon artist John Reid comes to the Schorr

"It’s Magic with John Reid" will return to the Schorr Family Firehouse Stage for three separate events on Saturday: an 11 a.m. children’s balloon workshop, a 2 p.m. magic show and a 5 p.m. balloon workshop for adults. Reid’s magic show is 50 minutes of interactive magic comedy for the entire family. During the show, Reid will bring as many as eight children to the stage to assist him. Tickets for the magic show are $10 for adults and $8 for children and seniors; tickets to the balloon workshops are $20 and can be purchased online at goodwilltheatre.net or by calling the box office at 607-772-2404, ext. 301. The Schorr Family Firehouse Stage is at 48 Willow St. in Johnson City.

3. Susquehanna Valley High presents 'Shrek'; Vestal produces '42nd Street'

Susquehanna Valley High School, at 1040 Conklin Road in Conklin, will let its freak flag fly with "Shrek the Musical," an adaptation of the Dreamworks animated film. The production will be held in the high school's auditorium at 7 p.m. Thursday through Saturday and 2 p.m. Sunday. Tickets are $8 for adults, and $6 for students and senior citizens. Tickets can be purchased in person or at the door. To purchase tickets ahead of time, visit saberstageproductions.ludus.com.

Also, Vestal High School will present “42nd Street” at 7 p.m. Thursday through Saturday and 1 p.m. Sunday in the Vestal High School Auditorium, 205 Woodlawn Drive in Vestal. The musical tells the story of Peggy Sawyer, a performer who hopes to get her big break on Broadway. Tickets are $10 for adults, and $8 for senior citizens and students, and will be available at the door one hour before each performance. For more information, visit vestal.stier.org/MusicDepartment.aspx.

4. Joseph Alston and Peter Lister to perform between Devils and Binghamton Heart games

Joseph Alston and Peter Lister, of the popular Americana band Milkweed, will perform at the Floyd L. Maines Veterans Memorial Arena at 7 p.m. Saturday after the 4 p.m. Binghamton Devils game against the Toronto Marlies, and prior to the 35th Binghamton Heart Cup hockey game at 8 p.m. Since 1985, Binghamton police have faced off against the Binghamton firefighters in the annual Heart Cup hockey contest to benefit the American Heart Association. Alston and Lister will perform on the UHS Soundstage between sections 19 and 20 of the arena concourse. As a duo, Alston and Lister perform many original songs ranging from folk to blues to bluegrass. For more on Alston and Lister, visit milkweedtheband.com and facebook.com/milkweedtheband. For more on the Binghamton Devils and the Binghamton Heart Cup, and to purchase tickets, visit binghamtondevils.com.

5. Binghamton Community Orchestra holds Winter Concert

The Binghamton Community Orchestra will welcome Guest Conductor Evan Meccarello and Mezzo-Soprano Jessica Best for its Winter Concert at 7 p.m. Saturday at the Binghamton East Middle School Auditorium, 167 E. Frederick St. in Binghamton. The concert will open with the overture to the opera “Fidelio,” the second of three offerings of the Beethoven Project in collaboration with the Binghamton Philharmonic, part of a year-and-a-half celebration of Ludwig van Beethoven’s 250th birthday. Also on the concert are Alexander Borodin’s Petite Suite, a selection from Maurice Ravel’s Mother Goose Suite, and contemporary composer Stephanie Berg’s "A Study in Red." Best will sing "Carmen" selections in French, with English synopses provided. Tickets are $12 for adults and $10 for seniors/students. Children 12 and younger are admitted for free. For more information, visit binghamtoncommunityorchestra.org.

6. BCAC and FASST host combined student art show

The annual High School Emerging Artist Competition has combined with the Fine Arts Society of the Southern Tier's (FASST) annual Young at Art Exhibition for a combined show and competition that will open Wednesday. The combined show and competition, for local high school art students in grades nine through 12, is part of the Binghamton Philharmonic's celebration of Beethoven’s 250th birthday. The art categories (painting, drawing, photography, sculpture and mixed media in any subject matter) have been maintained, but will also include a special one-time Beethoven-themed category. The show will be held at the former "Things Remembered" storefront at the Oakdale Mall and will run from Wednesday through March 27. The exhibition is judged by professional artists, and an awards ceremony will be held at 6 p.m. March 18. Participants will receive certificates from the Broome County Arts Council and FASST, and winners have the option to display their work with BCAC’s Artisan Gallery throughout the month of May. Gallery hours are 3 to 7 p.m. Tuesday through Friday. and 1 to 5 p.m. Saturday through Sunday. For more information, visit broomearts.org.

7. Drawing Marathon returns to BU Art Museum

The Binghamton University Art Museum's fifth annual Drawing Marathon will take place from 10 a.m. Friday through 10 a.m. Saturday at the museum. The event is free to the public. The 24-hour marathon will require 10 to 12 selected artists to complete a finished figure drawing in the time allotted. Artists will draw with charcoal on large sheets of prepared paper (provided by the organizers) from a live model who will pose for the entirety of the marathon. Short breaks will be given, but the artists will be at work for the run of the marathon. Visitors may observe the artists throughout the 24-hour period. Two cash prizes will be awarded on Saturday morning, Feb. 29: the jury prize of $1,000 and the people’s prize of $500. The people’s prize will be awarded on the basis of qualitative comments received by visitors to the marathon, as well as statements posted on the Binghamton University Art Museum Facebook page. The drawings will remain on view in the museum through Tuesday. The Binghamon University Art Museum is at 4400 Vestal Parkway East. For more information, visit facebook.com/BUArtMuseum or binghamton.edu/art-museum.

8. Jen Cork and Austin MacRae to play Main Fest Coffeehouse

The Maine Fest Coffeehouse will host singer songwriters Jen Cork and Austin MacRae at 7 p.m. Saturday at the Maine Federated Church Hall, 2615 Main St. (Route 26) in Maine. A suggested donation of $8 per person will benefit the Nanticoke Valley Historical Society. Tickets can be reserved by contacting themainefest@gmail.com. Refreshments will be available. For more information, visit facebook.com/events/326791161548634.

9. Swedish quintet stops by Chenango Sessions

The Chenango Sessions and WBDY 99.5 FM will present a concert and live recording session featuring the Swedish quintet Jaerv at 7:30 p.m. Tuesday at the Bundy Museum of History and Art, 129 Main St. in Binghamton. Jaerv performs folk music with both jazz and pop music, in a performance that includes energetic dance and free improvisations. All ages are welcome. The Chenango Sessions, hosted by Andru Bemis, is a weekly, one-hour, nationally syndicated radio program that features musicians playing in intimate spaces — living rooms, galleries and listening rooms — for small audiences around Binghamton. Audiences and artists are encouraged to interact, and the spirit of the live show is preserved in the radio program and recordings. There is a suggested donation of $15 to $20. To reserve seats, visit jaerv200303.brownpapertickets.com. For more information, visit andrubemis.com/chenango-sessions.

10. Chenango SPCA hosts annual Fur Ball

The Chenango SPCA (CSPCA) will host its 16th annual Fur Ball from 6 to 10 p.m. Saturday at the Canasawacta Country Club, 261 County Road 44 in Norwich. The event will be a semi-formal dinner and dance, featuring music by Brothers and Friends (formerly Brotherhood). The dinner will include a buffet of prime rib, herbed stuffed chicken, various pastas, salad, a mashed potato station and dessert bar. A complimentary glass of champagne will be donated by the Canasawacta Country Club. Tickets are available to purchase for $55 for an individual or $450 for a table of 10. To order tickets or for more information, visit chenangospca.org or call the CSPCA at 607-334-9724, ext 2.
